description:
Histoplasma capsulatum G186AR is a strain of the fungal pathogen Histoplasma capsulatum, which is the causative agent of the infectious disease histoplasmosis. Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus, meaning it can exist in two different forms: a mycelial (filamentous) form in the environment and a yeast-like form in the host.

The G186AR strain is a laboratory-derived variant of the wild-type H. capsulatum, which has been genetically modified and is commonly used in research studies. The "G186AR" designation indicates that this strain was isolated from a patient and subsequently attenuated (weakened) through repeated passages in the laboratory.

Histoplasma capsulatum G186AR is an important model organism for studying the biology, pathogenesis, and host-pathogen interactions of this fungus. Researchers often use this strain to investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying Histoplasma virulence, the host immune response, and the development of potential therapeutic interventions against histoplasmosis.
